description: From Middle English overchargen, equivalent to over- +â€Ž charge.

entries.meaning: An excessive charge in an account.
Any amount erroneously charged to a customer above the correct price for a product or service.

verbs.description: overcharge (third-person singular simple present overcharges, present participle overcharging, simple past and past participle overcharged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To charge (somebody) more money than the correct amount or to surpass a certain limit while charging a bill.
(transitive) To continue to charge (an electrical device) beyond its capacity.
To charge (someone) with an inflated number or degree of legal charges (for example, charging them with a more serious crime than was committed); to upcharge.
(transitive, dated) To charge or load too heavily; to burden; to oppress.
examples: it serves to no better use but only to labour and overcharge the ships' sides in any grown seas and foul weather.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To fill too full; to crowd.
examples: Our language is naturally overcharged with consonants.
